abstract: This isn’t the recession they were looking for.
lead_paragraph: From an economic point of view, 2023 will go down in the record books as one of the best years ever — a year in which inflation came down amazingly fast at no visible cost, defying the predictions of many economists that disinflation would require years of high unemployment.
headline: Beware Economists Who Won’t Admit They Were Wrong
keywords: Biden, Joseph R Jr;United States Economy;Supply Chain;Inflation (Economics);Labor and Jobs;Wages and Salaries;Federal Reserve System;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)

abstract: To combat authoritarianism, first combat fatalism.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Donald Trump was elected in 2016, I spoke to a friend in Istanbul about my boundless horror, and while I can’t remember the exact words she said in response, they amounted to “Welcome to my world.” I told her about all the protests breaking out, and she gently warned me not to get my hopes up. She’d also demonstrated against Turkey’s authoritarian president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, she said, but eventually those protests had died out, and ours would too.
headline: Make a New Year’s Resolution to Fight Trump
keywords: Presidential Election of 2024;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Trump, Donald J;United States Politics and Government;Democracy (Theory and Philosophy);Run for Something (Nonprofit)

abstract: After an indie-film breakout just four years ago, he was headed to the A list. But a criminal conviction immediately jeopardized his leading-man status.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to mint a new movie star these days, which is why people in Hollywood were so high on Jonathan Majors. Cerebral and charismatic with the muscular build of an action hero, the 34-year-old actor had risen quickly from acclaimed indies to big blockbusters. This was supposed to be the year that would turn him into an A-lister, aided by the massive releases of “Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania” and “Creed III,” as well as an Oscar contender, the prestige drama “Magazine Dreams.”
headline: The Fast Rise and Staggering Fall of Jonathan Majors

abstract: Tommy José Stathes might have the largest collection of vintage animated films in the world stuffed into a storage unit in Queens.

abstract: There’s something uniquely American in both its wanton borrowing from existing tradition and its naked admission of artificiality.
lead_paragraph: Forget April: In middle school, November was always, inevitably, the cruelest month for me. Starting around Thanksgiving, my friends would gather in the locker room after gym class to consult one another on the best strategies for the holiday season. Crouched over Best Buy and Circuit City catalogs, they would argue the merits of the PlayStation 2 versus the Xbox. Should they beg for the latest edition of NBA 2K, a game that would be obsolete within nine months? Or Halo?
headline: Yes, Kwanzaa Is Made Up. That’s Why It’s Great
keywords: Kwanzaa (Celebration);Holidays and Special Occasions;California;Black People;Blacks

abstract: The court should rule on the question of presidential immunity, and it should do so on an accelerated timetable.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is considering whether to take up the question of presidential immunity — that is, the idea that a president, by virtue of the unique nature of the office, is entitled to exceedingly broad protections from legal consequences for statements made and actions taken while in office. If the court takes up that question in a case regarding Donald Trump, it will have profound consequences for both the 2024 election and the bigger question of presidential power.
headline: Trump Has Always Wanted to Be King. The Supreme Court Should Rid Him of That Delusion.

abstract: With “The Zone of Interest,” Jonathan Glazer is just the latest director to confront the problem.
lead_paragraph: Poetry makes nothing happen, W.H. Auden said in 1939, when words must have seemed especially impotent; but cinema is another matter. For several decades after the end of the Second World War, what’s come to be seen as its central catastrophe — the near-total destruction of the European Jews — was consigned to the status of a footnote. The neglect was rooted in guilt: Many nations eagerly collaborated in the killing, while others did nothing to prevent it. Consumed by their own suffering, most people simply didn’t want to know, and a conspiracy of silence was established.
headline: How Do You Make a Movie About the Holocaust?
keywords: Glazer, Jonathan;The Zone of Interest (Movie);Holocaust and the Nazi Era;Movies;Jews and Judaism;Black Earth: The Holocaust as History and Warning (Book);Holocaust (TV Program);Schindler's List (Movie)

abstract: Every December, carolers flock to a dairy farm in New York to serenade the herd.

About 20 feet below the balcony, on the floor of the large domed barn, two of the half-dozen dairy cows were butting heads. As the grazing heifers lifted their horns, their playful roughhousing seemed like a display of holiday cheer.
headline: Even Cows Need Some Holiday Cheer

abstract: There’s a lot to like about this musical film version of Alice Walker’s novel, but the story remains slippery to would-be adapters.

abstract: Ukraine’s counteroffensive sputtered, but President Volodymyr Zelensky argued that Russia, too, “failed to achieve any results” on the ground, while Ukraine had successes at sea.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky pushed back against doubts about Ukraine’s battlefield prospects and about the support of its allies, telling reporters on Tuesday that his country is not losing the war and is prepared to negotiate with Russia, but only on its own terms.
headline: Zelensky, After Tough Year on Battlefield, Insists Ukraine Will Prevail
keywords: Zelensky, Volodymyr;Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Ukraine;Politics and Government;Foreign Aid;International Relations;Defense and Military Forces;Russia

abstract: Charles Donohoe, one of the members of the extremist group who cooperated with prosecutors, was sentenced to 40 months, slightly more than the time he has already been credited for.
lead_paragraph: A former leader of the Proud Boys who helped the government investigate and prosecute others in the far-right group involved in the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced on Tuesday to 40 months in prison for his own role in the assault.
headline: Proud Boys Member Who Helped Prosecution Sentenced in Jan. 6 Attack
keywords: Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right;Proud Boys;Donohoe, Charles (1988- );Decisions and Verdicts;Presidential Election of 2020

abstract: The tally reflects the extraordinary chaos and paralysis that gripped the House in 2023, when lawmakers did more voting but less lawmaking than at any time in the past decade.
lead_paragraph: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the former speaker, had a positive spin on the five days and record-breaking 15 voting rounds it took him to win the gavel in January. “Because it took this long,” he said after the ordeal, “now we learned how to govern.”
headline: House Dysfunction by the Numbers: 724 Votes, Only 27 Laws Enacted
keywords: Law and Legislation;United States Politics and Government;Federal Budget (US);Republican Party;House of Representatives;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Schiff, Adam B;Tlaib, Rashida;Bowman, Jamaal;Johnson, Mike (1972- );McCarthy, Kevin (1965- );Santos, George (1988- )

abstract: Cantiere Hambirreria brings its Pisa Tower of hamburgers to Kenmare Street, Che provides produce in an all-day cafe in Bedford-Stuvesant, Brooklyn, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: For some time now, Nick Hatsatouris, a restaurateur with places in East Hampton, N.Y., and West Hollywood, Calif., has had his eye on New York. He’s taken over the dining areas in the historic Evelyn Hotel, in NoMad, which had been run by the chef Jonathan Benno and closed in 2021. “It’s a beautiful building in a thriving neighborhood so I saw it as a good opportunity,” he said. First up is the bar area, now called the Tusk Bar, which Mr. Hatsatouris said is a reference to the walrus and oysters in Lewis Carroll’s “The Walrus and the Carpenter.” Oysters figure importantly on the menu, as does other seafood like king crab, which is piled into a club sandwich. The area is now done in earth tones with touches of gold and other colors; the open kitchen is no more. The chefs Jeremiah Stone and Fabián von Hauske Valtierra, of Wildair downtown, are the menu consultants. The chef de cuisine is Vincent Edwards. Next month the high-ceilinged dining room a few steps up from the bar will become Brass, an American take on a brasserie, and the Ninepin Café will be installed, for casual all-day dining, near the hotel entrance.
headline: The Tusk Bar Sets Up in the Evelyn Hotel, in NoMad
keywords: Restaurants;Bars and Nightclubs;New York City

abstract: He made his name in the 1980s with the Waitresses and the Psychedelic Furs, but his roots were in the exploratory jazz of Eric Dolphy and Ornette Coleman.
lead_paragraph: Weakened by surgery to remove a tumor near his pancreas in January, followed by six months of chemotherapy, the high-wattage saxophonist Mars Williams learned this past summer that his treatment options were nearly exhausted.
headline: Mars Williams, 68, Saxophonist Who Straddled New Wave and Jazz, Dies
keywords: Williams, Mars (1955-2023);Deaths (Obituaries);Pop and Rock Music;Jazz;Nineteen Hundred Eighties;Saxophones;Waitresses, The (Music Group);Psychedelic Furs (Music Group)

abstract: Despite holding more than 700 votes this year, the House only managed to pass 27 bills that have made it into law, thanks to tiny majorities, divided government and a right wing bent on constraining government.
lead_paragraph: In a year of divided government, when House Republicans were even divided against themselves, Congress was historically unproductive. The House has passed just 27 bills that were signed into law by President Biden. Still to come is the annual military policy bill that the House cleared for Mr. Biden last week but he has yet to sign.
headline: The 27 Bills That Became Law in 2023
keywords: House of Representatives;Republican Party;Law and Legislation;Veterans Affairs Department;Federal Budget (US)

abstract: The French leader was elected twice on a vow to keep populism at bay. But his bill received rare support from the far right, setting off a crisis in his party.
lead_paragraph: France’s Parliament late Tuesday approved an immigration overhaul that was made tougher under right-wing pressure, securing a legislative win for President Emmanuel Macron but risking a political crisis for a leader elected twice on centrist vows to keep far-right populism at bay.
headline: Macron Compromises With Right to Pass Immigration Overhaul
keywords: France;Illegal Immigration;Macron, Emmanuel (1977- );Law and Legislation;Politics and Government;Foreign Workers;Immigration and Emigration;National Rally (France);Darmanin, Gerald;Le Pen, Marine;Europe

abstract: Also, a challenge to Texas’s immigration law. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Following Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks in Israel, President Biden emphasized his support for Israel’s war effort and sent weapons to Israel for its campaign against Hamas. Recently, his administration has pressured Israeli leaders to scale back their military operations. That strategy has been disapproved by many voters in both parties, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll.
headline: Voters Broadly Disapprove of Biden’s Strategy on Gaza
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );United States International Relations;Polls and Public Opinion;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Israel;Gaza Strip

abstract: Women, sex and Jewish mothers were just some of the targets of his popular satirical writing in books, essays, screenplays and more.
lead_paragraph: Dan Greenburg, the prolific humorist, best-selling author, essayist, playwright and screenwriter whose satirical prose examined Jewish angst, women and sex, and who later produced a series of humorous children’s books, died on Monday in the Bronx. He was 87.
headline: Dan Greenburg, Who Poked Fun With His Pen, Dies at 87
keywords: Greenburg, Dan (1936-2023);Books and Literature;Writing and Writers;Comedy and Humor;Jews and Judaism;How to Be a Jewish Mother (Book);Deaths (Obituaries)

abstract: Efforts to speed military assistance to Ukraine are being punted to 2024, as negotiators remain short of a deal for aid Republicans have demanded to pair with a border crackdown.
lead_paragraph: Congress gave up Tuesday on a last-ditch bid to speed through emergency military aid to Ukraine before the end of the year, as negotiators failed to cement a deal that Republicans have demanded tying the money to a crackdown on migration across the U.S. border with Mexico.
headline: Congress Abandons Ukraine Aid Until Next Year as Border Talks Continue
keywords: United States Politics and Government;Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Senate;Schumer, Charles E;McConnell, Mitch;Illegal Immigration;Foreign Aid

abstract: The decision, the first by a court to find that Donald Trump is ineligible to hold office again because he engaged in insurrection, is likely to put a monumental case before the U.S. Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Colorado’s top court ruled on Tuesday that former President Donald J. Trump is disqualified from holding office again because he engaged in insurrection with his actions leading up to the Jan. 6 storming of the Capitol, an explosive ruling that is likely to put the basic contours of the 2024 election in the hands of the U.S. Supreme Court.
headline: Trump Is Disqualified From 2024 Ballot, Colorado Court Says in Explosive Ruling
keywords: Colorado;Trump, Donald J;Presidential Election of 2024;Decisions and Verdicts;Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution);Supreme Courts (State);Supreme Court (US);United States Politics and Government;Republican Party;Wallace, Sarah B;Samour, Carlos A Jr;Primaries and Caucuses

abstract: The minority leader took an oblique swipe at Donald Trump’s rhetoric about migrants “poisoning the blood” of the country, but others like Senator Tommy Tuberville defended him.
lead_paragraph: When Mitch McConnell, the top Republican in the Senate, was asked about former President Donald J. Trump’s now-standard stump line claiming that immigrants are “poisoning the blood of our country,” Senator McConnell delivered an indirect but contemptuous response.
headline: McConnell and Other Senate Republicans Criticize Trump’s Talk on Immigrants
keywords: Immigration and Emigration;Illegal Immigration;United States Politics and Government;Presidential Election of 2024;Republican Party;McConnell, Mitch;Thune, John R;Trump, Donald J;Vance, J D;Schumer, Charles E
